revised_title: Evidence of a Large Extinct Lizard: Notiosaurus dentatus from Pleistocene Deposits in New South Wales, Australia
tldr: Professor Owen describes a fragment of jaw with teeth from a fossil found in Pleistocene deposits at Cuddie Springs, New South Wales. He compares the fossil to known recent and fossil Saurians and applies a microscopic test to the bone and tooth tissues. Owen concludes that the fossil belongs to a large, carnivorous lacertian reptile, distinct from the largest existing toothed and pleurodont lizard, Hydrosaurus giganteus. He proposes the name Notiosaurus dentatus for this extinct pleurodont Saurian.
